CROSS REFERENCES
Theft of services - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
 
705.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Communications system" includes community antenna television and the
receipt, transmission, and distribution of voices, sounds, writings, signals,
pictures, visions, images, or any type of closed circuit transmission or signal
transmission by means of electrical impulses.
   (b)   "Community antenna television system" includes community antenna
television and the receipt, transmission, and distribution of voices, sound,
signals, pictures, visual images, or any other type of closed circuit
transmission or signal transmission by means of electrical impulses.
   (c)   "Company," as used in this chapter includes any person, partnership,
corporation or other entity granted a franchise to operate a community antenna
television system or communications system within this Municipality.
   (d)   "Franchise" means a grant or privilege extended by the municipality
involving a contract between the franchise applicant and the Municipality.
   (e)   "Radio" means a system for transmission of audio signals by means of
electrical impulses by means of wires.
   (f)   "Streets" means any duly dedicated street, highway, lane, avenue,
sidewalk, alley, bridge, boulevards, or other public place in the Municipality,
including all public right-of-ways and street right-of-ways.
   (g)   "Television" means a system for transmission of audio signals and
visual images by means of electrical impulses by means of wires.
      (1980 Code 122.01)
705.02  FRANCHISE REQUIRED TO OPERATE.
   No person shall operate a community antenna television system or television
or radio transmission business to transmit television or radio signals by means
of wires placed on poles in the streets or underground wires, pipes, conduits,
and other fixtures in the Municipality without obtaining a franchise from
Council.
(1980 Code 122.02)
705.03  FRANCHISE APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Any person desiring to operate a community antenna television system or
television or radio transmission business under the provisions of this chapter
shall make application therefor in writing to the Municipal Administrator. The
application shall contain:
   (a)   The names and addresses of persons interested in the application,
including all partners, if a partnership, and all officers, if a corporation.
   (b)   The proposed plan of construction and method of distribution of
television and radio signals.
   (c)   A schedule of rates to be charged customers.
   (d)   A current profit and loss statement and balance sheet of the
applicant's business certified to by a certified public accountant.
   (e)   A statement indicating liability insurance coverage of not less than
$25,000 as to any one accident, and not less than $200,000 aggregate in any
single policy year; and against liability due to bodily injury or to death of
persons, not less than $100,000 as to any one person, and not less than
$300,000 as to any one accident.
   (f)   A statement indicating ability to furnish a performance bond to the
Municipality in any sum and form required by council with sufficient sureties
thereon guaranteeing payment of all sums which may at any time become due from
the applicant to the Municipality under the terms of the requested franchise
and guaranteeing of faithful performance of all obligations of the applicant.
   (g)   A schedule of the amount proposed to be paid to the Municipality as a
percentage of the gross receipts from monthly service charges.
(1980 Code 122.03)
705.04  ISSUANCE OF FRANCHISE.
   A franchise to transmit television or radio signals or other electrical
impulses by wires shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter on
approval thereof by Council, who may approve a franchise for the transmittal of
television signals, radio signals, or other electrical impulses combined, or
separate franchises for television, radio, and other electrical impulses.
(1980 Code 122.04)
705.05  REVOCATION OF FRANCHISE.
   A franchise granted under this chapter may be revoked by the Municipal
Administrator where it appears that the holder thereof has not complied with
the franchise or is violating any municipal ordinance or state or federal law.
(1980 Code 122.05)
705.06  TRANSFER OF FRANCHISE.
   No holder of a franchises granted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter
shall sell, assign, or otherwise transfer its system or any interests or rights
arising from the ownership or operation of said system and the franchise
granted therefore without notice to and written approve of the Municipality
which shall not be unreasonably withheld. The rights and privileges arising by
the grant of such franchise shall not be assignable or transferable directly or
indirectly in any proceeding in bankruptcy, trusteeship, receivership, or by
operation of any law and in the event of any such assignment or transfer, any
such grant of franchise shall automatically terminate forthwith.
(1980 Code 122.06; Ord. 18-90.)
705.07  GRANT OF AUTHORITY.
   Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
705.06, all of the rights in, title to, and interests of any person,
corporation, partnership or other entity granted a franchise pursuant to this
chapter shall be assignable for collateral purposes, without prior consent of
the Municipality, by the pledge of those rights, title, and interest to secure
indebtedness of the franchise holder or affiliates thereof. However, no such
assignment or transfer shall be deemed to relieve, excuse or otherwise waive
the franchise holder of the duties, liabilities, and responsibilities imposed
by the provisions of this chapter.
(1980 Code 122.15; Ord. 18-90.)
705.08  USE OF EXISTING POLES.
   The company shall, on agreement with the owners, use existing poles, towers,
or other facilities wherever possible, and it shall be the sole responsibility
of the company to negotiate and enter into any and all contracts with the
owners of such facilities to secure the necessary space thereon or therein for
its operation under this chapter. It is the stated intention of the
Municipality that the number of new or additional poles constructed by the
company under the provisions of this chapter be kept at a minimum, and to the
extent necessary to carry out this intention, the company on securing such
agreement with other holders of public permits and franchises is granted the
right to use existing poles, towers, and other facilities. Except for companies
furnishing the same or similar services, the company shall permit any utility
or holder of public permits or franchises for the use of streets for the
erection of poles and pole line facilities, by appropriate contract or
agreement negotiated by the parties, to use any and all facilities constructed
or erected in the streets by the company. All the agreements and installations
shall be subject to this code and all existing and future regulatory ordinances
of the municipality. Plans for all such installations shall be submitted to the
Municipal Administrator for his approval, prior to installation, which approval
shall not be unreasonably withheld and shall be erected under his supervision.
(1980 Code 122.17; Ord. 10-81.)
705.09  USE OF POLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   To the extent that the company is unable to use particular poles, towers,
and other facilities, due to refusal by owners of such facilities, it may be
required and may receive approval as set forth in Section
705.08.  In the event that existing poles, towers, and other facilities are on
private property, the company agrees to secure easements where required, from
the property owners. When existing utilities are underground and no poles
exist, the company agrees to install its facilities underground.
(1980 Code 122.18; Ord. 10-81.)
705.10  REMOVAL OF POLES AND EQUIPMENT; TEMPORARY REMOVAL.
   (a)   The company's poles, wires, and appurtenances shall be located,
erected, and maintained so as not to endanger the lives of persons, or to
interfere with street improvements the Municipality may deem proper to make, or
with facilities of present franchise holders, or to hinder unnecessarily or
obstruct the free use of the streets. Removal of poles or equipment when
deemed  necessary by the Municipal Administrator or his authorized
representative, to avoid such interference for relocation of a street, or
change in the grade of a street will be at the company's expense except as
provided in division (b) below, provided that the company shall be given not
less than 48 hours advance notice to arrange such removal.
   (b)   The company on the request of any person holding a building moving
permit issued by the Municipality will temporarily raise or lower its wires to
permit the moving of the building. The expense of such temporary removal,
raising, or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same
and the Municipality shall have the authority to require such payment in
advance. The company shall be given not less than 48 hours advance notice to
arrange for such temporary wire changes.
(1980 Code 122.19; Ord. 10-81.)
705.11  COMPLIANCE WITH CITY AND STATE LAW.
   (a)   Construction and maintenance of the communications system shall be in
accordance with the provisions of this Code and other ordinances and
regulations of the Municipality affecting those installations. The company
shall restore all property damaged by such construction or maintenance to as
good a condition as existed on such property prior thereto.
   (b)   All installations of equipment shall be durable and installed in
accordance with good engineering practice and of sufficient height as directed
by the Municipal Administrator, the code, and state law so as not to interfere
unduly with the rights of the public or individual property owner.
(1980 Code 122.20; Ord. 10-81.)
705.12  MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF SYSTEM.
   (a)   In the maintenance and operation of its communications system in the
streets, and in the course of any new construction or addition to its
facilities the company shall proceed so as to cause the least possible
inconvenience to the general public, and shall not unduly obstruct the streets,
impede traffic, or interfere with travel by the public.
   (b)   The company shall not make any installations across any public street
or cause to be made any opening or obstruction in the streets without first
having obtained the permission of the Municipal Administrator.
(1980 Code 122.21; Ord. 10-81.)
705.13  INDEMNIFICATION; INSURANCE.
   (a)   The company shall indemnify, protect, and save harmless the
Municipality and its agents and employees from any and all loss or damage
arising out of, or claims for injury or death to any person, or damage to any
property incurred by or asserted the Municipality or its agents or employees,
directly or indirectly, by reason of the operations of the company and the
grant herein authorized.
   (b)   The company shall carry insurance, to protect the parties hereto from
and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses, and
liabilities which may arise or result, directly or indirectly, from or by
reason of, such loss, injury, or damage. The amounts of such insurance against
liability due to physical damages to property shall not be less than $350,000
and against liability due to bodily injury or to death of persons, not less
than $500,000 as to any one person and not less than $500,000 as to any one
accident. All insurance required by this chapter shall be and remain in full
force and effect for the entire life of this chapter. The policy of insurance
or a certificate or certificates thereof shall be approved by the Solicitor and
be deposited with and kept on file in the office of the Municipal Clerk, and
shall reflect the Municipality as the named insured.
(1980 Code 122.22; Ord. 10-81.)
705.14  INTERFERENCE.
   Installation and maintenance shall be such that no interference is caused to
existing communications systems and so as not to distort or interfere with
direct off the air television signals. (1980 Code 122.23; Ord. 10-81.)
705.15  CHANNELS.
   (a)   The company shall maintain a communications system with a minimum
channel capacity of 54 channels with at least 40 active channels. The company
shall have the responsibility for maintaining a receiving tower and necessary
equipment at a location which will insure adequate service to the Municipality
and which will have the necessary antennas and electronic equipment to supply
the service by the company. The listing of the programming currently provided
by the company, which is attached to Ordinance 18-90, shall be considered a
reasonable facsimile of the minimum service to be provided by the company.
   (b)   The company shall make available at their cost a color camera,
character generation, and associated electronic equipment to permit the
Municipality and/or local school system to originate televised coverage of
meetings or other public activities.
(1980 Code 122.24; Ord. 18-90.)
705.16  PAYMENTS TO MUNICIPALITY.
   The company shall pay to the Municipality 3% of the gross proceeds received
from all revenues collected by the company from inhabitants of the Municipality
including but not limited to charges for premium channels, installations, and
other auxiliary services, so long as the company owns or utilizes facilities in
the streets in the Municipality. Payments shall be made on an annual basis,
shall be accompanied by a detailed statement of the gross revenues collected
from within the Municipality and shall be made on such other terms and
conditions as shall be reasonably determined by the Municipal Administrator.
The Municipal Administrator shall have the right to cause an audit by the
Municipality or by an independent agency with regard to the gross proceeds.
(1980 Code 122.25; Ord. 10-81.)
705.17  APPLICABLE LAW.
   The Municipality and the company agree to abide by the rules established by
the Cable Communications Act of 1984, the Federal Communications Commission,
the United States Congress, and any other rule making body which affects the
operation of a cable television system. Furthermore, both parties agree to
abide by any modifications, amendments, or additions to any existing rules or
any newly established rules which affect the cable television industry and its
relationship with the community.
(1980 Code 122.26; Ord. 18-90.)
705.18  REVOCATION; TERMINATION; REMOVAL OF POLES AND TOWERS.
   (a)   The Municipality reserves the right to revoke the rights herein
granted if the company fails, after 90 days notice by certified mail, to comply
with the conditions, provisions, or regulations under this chapter.
   (b)   The company, at any time during the effective period of this chapter,
may terminate its agreement hereunder on giving the Municipality 90 days
written notice of such termination. The company shall pay the Municipality
within 30 days of the effective date of such termination, all sums due to the
Municipality under the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)   The company shall remove all poles, towers, and related facilities
herein authorized and shall restore the property in as good a condition for
public use as the abutting portions thereof at the company's own cost and
expense within 90 days after the expiration, termination, or revocation of this
chapter.
(1980 Code 122.27; Ord. 10-81.)
705.19  EXTENSION OF SYSTEM.
   In the event of future development of the Municipality for residential
purposes or expansion of the geographic boundaries of the Municipality to
include residential uses, the holder of any franchise granted under the
authority of this chapter shall extend its communications system to any such
residential area within 12 months after the density of that area has reached 25
single-family residences per cable mile. In calculating the cable mile, the
distance from the existing cable to said residential area shall be taken into
account. The distance from a street or easement to a residence shall not be
taken into account.
(1980 Code 122.28; Ord. 18-90.)
705.20  INVESTIGATION; HEARING.
   (a)   Any inquiry, proceeding, investigation, or other action, including
amendments to this chapter, to be taken or proposed to be taken by the Council
in regard to the operations of the company's cable television system, other
than as provided in Section
705.21, but including action in regard to a change in subscription rates, shall
be taken only after 30 days public notice of such action or proposed action is
published in a local daily or weekly newspaper having general circulation in
the Municipality. A copy of such action or proposed action shall be served by
certified mail directly on the company, and the company shall be given an
opportunity to respond in writing or at any hearing as shall be specified by
the Council, and general members of the public shall be given an opportunity to
respond or comment on the action or proposed action.
   (b)   The public notice required by this section shall state clearly the
action or proposed action to be taken, the time provided for response and the
person in authority to whom such responses should be addressed, and such other
procedures as may be specified by Council. If a hearing is to be held, the
public notice shall give the date and time of such hearing, whether public
participation will be allowed and the procedures by which such participation
may be obtained. The company is a necessary part to any hearing conducted in
regard to its operation.
(1980 Code 122.29; Ord. 10-81.)
705.21  COMPLAINT PROCEDURE; PRORATION.
   (a)   The company shall maintain a local business office and such business
office of the company shall remain open during normal business hours (at least
from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on weekdays). The office shall have a publicly
listed telephone. Any complaints regarding service shall be responded to and
acted on by the company as soon as possible, which normally shall be within a
maximum of three business days from receipt of such complaint.
   (b)   During the term of this franchise and any renewals thereof, in order
to assure proper service any change in the address or telephone number of the
company shall be promptly reported to the Municipality and to the residents of
the Municipality by appropriate announcements or viewing cards on the
origination channels of the system.
   (c)   Any subscriber to the services of the company shall report any outages
or failures of reception as set forth above. A subscriber may demand of the
company a prorate discount of the charge for transmission services in the event
of such outage or failure. In the event of any outage which occurs at the fault
of the company for a period longer than 48 hours from the time of notice, the
company shall compute such prorata discount (beginning at the time of the
demand) and reflect the same in the next billing to such subscriber.
(1980 Code 122.30; Ord. 10-81.)
705.22  TAXES.
   The company shall abide by and carefully follow each and all of the
regulations in Chapter
171  relative to income tax, specifically including the withholding of taxes
due from those employees of the company who work within the corporate limits of
the Municipality.
(1980 Code 122.31; Ord. 10-81.)
705.23  MUNICIPALITY TO BE KEPT INFORMED.
   The company shall have the responsibility to keep the Municipality fully
informed with regard to regulations, or changes therein, or any other action by
state or federal agencies, including the Federal Communications Commission,
which regulations, changes, or decisions would have an effect on the
administration of this chapter, and the delivery of the service.
(1980 Code 122.32; Ord. 10-81.)
705.24  SERVICE TO DESIGNATED AGENCIES.
   The company shall reserve one channel for educational programming, and shall
furnish, according to the installation charges set forth herein, one connection
to the public and parochial schools, including technical schools, colleges, and
universities, in the Municipality and shall furnish the same without charge for
monthly service. Any such school may install at its expense such additional
connections for classroom purposes as it desires, provided that such
installation shall not interfere with the operations of the company's system,
and that the quality and manner of installation of such additional connections
shall have been approved by the company and shall comply with all municipal,
state, and federal laws and regulations. In addition, the applicant shall
furnish to the Municipality without charge such connections as may be required
for regulation and supervision of the communications system, not to exceed
three, and shall provide without charge monthly service thereafter, provided
that such connections be located in public buildings and installation charges
shall be paid by the Municipality according to the charges set forth herein.
(1980 Code 122.33; Ord. 10-81.)
705.25  FILING OF MAP AND FINANCIAL STATEMENT.
   The company shall file with the Municipality at the end of the fiscal year
of the company a map showing the area of the Municipality being served and a
copy of the yearly financial statement of the company as reported to the IRS.
(1980 Code 122.34; Ord. 10-81.)
705.26  SALE OF TELEVISIONS PROHIBITED.
   The company and its employees shall not engage in sales, service, rental, or
leasing of television receivers, radio receivers, or television or radio
receiver parts and accessories. The company and its employees shall not require
or attempt to direct its subscribers to deal with any particular firm or
persons in regards to sales, service, rentals, or leasing of television or
radio receiver parts and accessories.
(1980 Code 122.35; Ord. 10-81.)
705.27  SUBSCRIPTIONS.
   Subscribers to the company's service shall not be required to assure the
company that they will subscribe to the company's service to any given length
of time.
(1980 Code 122.36; Ord. 10-81.)
705.28  TAMPERING WITH INSTALLATION OR EQUIPMENT.
   Subscribers shall operate only one receiver at a time from each outlet
installed by the company and shall refrain from tampering with the installation
in any way. The company shall have the right to discontinue service to any
subscriber tampering with its installation or related equipment or attempting
in any way to use the company service except as intended by the company. The
subscriber violating these conditions shall not be entitled to any rebate or
other consideration by the company.
(1980 Code 122.37; Ord. 10-81.)
705.29  BOND.
   The company shall furnish a bond to the Municipality in the amount of
$10,000 in such form and with such sureties as shall be acceptable to the
Municipality, guaranteeing the faithful performance of all of the obligations
of the company under the terms of this chapter.
(1980 Code 122.39; Ord. 10-81.)
705.30  HIRING AND EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES.
   It is duly recognized by Council that the company has expressed interest to
operate a local business, service office within the Municipality. This intent
has been considered as a good faith proposal from the company in acceptance of
the company's proposal and is encouraged and anticipated. The company further
has expressed its intent to hire locally the personnel necessary to service the
system. This intent likewise is encouraged and anticipated if at all possible.
(1980 Code 122.40; Ord. 10-81.)
705.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Sections
705.01 to
705.06 shall, for the first offense, be guilty of a misdemeanor of the third
degree, and for each subsequent offense shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the
first degree. Each day's violation shall be considered a separate offense.
CHAPTER 711
Drive-In Restaurants
711.01   Definition.
711.02   Special curbing required.
711.03   Maintenance of curbing; location.
711.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Turning in to drive-in - see TRAF.
331.11
Driving onto roadway - see TRAF.
331.23
 
711.01  DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter "drive-in restaurant" includes all
establishments where prepared food is sold at the vehicle of patrons on the
property of the restaurant operator, but excluding grocery stores, bakeries,
businesses limited to the sale of ice cream, or similar businesses.
(1980 Code 115.01)
711.02  SPECIAL CURBING REQUIRED.
   The owners or operators of drive-in restaurants shall provide substantial
rounded curbing or humps consisting of asphalt, concrete, or similar
obstruction across the entire driveway entrances or egress portions of their
premises providing for the passage of motor vehicles between such premises and
the public street, except that a portion of the driveway at either end of such
curb or hump may be so constructed as to provide adequate drainage to the
street. Such curb or hump shall be not less than two inches high and so
constructed as to require the slow passage of motor vehicles. The height of the
curb or hump shall be measured from the finished grade of the premises or the
adjoining sidewalk where sidewalks are provided, whichever is higher. It shall
not be more than 12 inches wide for each two inches in height, and should be
painted traffic yellow.
(1980 Code 115.02)
711.03  MAINTENANCE OF CURBING; LOCATION.
   The curb or hump described in Section
711.02 shall be provided within 15 days of the effective date of this chapter.
The curb or hump shall be maintained in good condition and shall be so rounded
as not to be a nuisance to pedestrian travel. If such curb or hump is not
located on the owner's or operator's premises immediately adjoining the street
line, at each driveway entrance, the owner or operator shall obtain the
approval of the Municipal Administrator for another location on such premises
to accomplish the objects of these sections.
(1980 Code 115.03)
711.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
701.99 for general code penalty.)
CHAPTER 723
Peddlers, Solicitors, and Canvassers
GENERAL PROVISIONS
723.01    Definitions.
723.02    Registration or license required.
723.03    Furnishing information; fee;  license; registration.
723.04    Restrictions.
723.05    Trespassing in violation of posted signs.
723.99    Penalty.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch.1716
Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et. seq.
Littering - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
 
 
723.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this Chapter:
   (a)   “Canvasser” means any person who engages in canvassing.
   (b)   “Canvassing” means traveling by foot, automobile, truck or other type
of conveyance to private residences within the City including any house,
apartment or other dwelling unit for the purpose of obtaining or seeking to
obtain or influence the opinions of the residents of the City but without
obtaining or seeking or obtain funds for any cause whatsoever.
   (c)   “Peddler” means any person who engages in peddling.
   (d)   “Peddling” means traveling by foot, automobile, truck, or any other
type of conveyance from place to place, door to door or from street to street,
taking or attempting to take orders for profit by the sale of services, goods,
wares, foodstuffs, beverages, merchandise or any other property, tangible or
intangible, of any nature whatsoever, for immediate or future delivery.
   (e)   “Solicitor” means any person who engages in soliciting.
   (f)   “Soliciting” means traveling, means  traveling by foot, automobile,
truck or other type of conveyance to private residences within the City
including any house, apartment or other dwelling unit for the purpose of
obtaining or seeking to obtain funds for any cause whatsoever except for
charitable purposes.  The solicitation by a newspaper carrier of customers for
a newspaper that the carrier regularly delivers or will regularly deliver shall
not be included in this definition, nor shall solicitation for political
purposes be included in this definition.
      (Ord. 1-12.  Passed 3-12-12.)
723.02  REGISTRATION OR LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall canvass or solicit within the City without first
registering with the Police Department.  A separate registration must be made
for every canvasser, solicitor, agent or employee canvassing or soliciting
within the City.  Registration under this section does not apply to a canvasser
or solicitor who is engaged in religious proselytizing or political speech.
   (b)   No person shall peddle within the City without first obtaining a
license issued pursuant to this Chapter. 
(Ord. 1-12.  Passed 3-12-12.)
723.03  FURNISHING INFORMATION; FEE; LICENSE; REGISTRATION.
   (a)   Each canvasser, peddler and solicitor required to register or obtain a
license from the City shall, prior to commencing canvassing, peddling or
soliciting (hereinafter described as activity), furnish the Police Department
with the following information on forms provided by the City:
      (1)   Name, date of birth and social security number of applicant.
      (2)   Complete permanent and local address of applicant.
      (3)   Name and address of the person, firm, corporation or association
for whom the activity will be performed.
      (4)   A description of the nature of the business and the services,
goods, wares, foodstuffs, beverages, merchandise or any other property to be
sold in sufficient detail to identify the subject matter of the activity in
which the applicant will engage.
      (5)   The proposed dates and times of the activity and the routes to be
followed in conducting said activity.
      (6)   The make, model, year, color and license plate number of motor
vehicles or a detailed description of other conveyances used by the applicant
during the period of the activity within the City and the applicant’s driver’s
license number and the state of issuance.
   (b)   Any registration made or license issued under this Chapter shall
expire on December 31 of the year initially issued and must be renewed for each
calendar year thereafter.
   (c)   The application for a license shall be accompanied by the payment of
the applicable fee as determined from time to time by Council.  There shall be
no fee for a registration made under this Chapter.
(Ord. 1-12.  Passed 3-12-12.)
723.04  RESTRICTIONS.
   Every person to whom this chapter applies shall be governed by the following
rules and regulations:
   (a)   All circulars, samples or other matter shall be handed to an occupant
of the property or left in a secure place on the premises.
   (b)   No person subject to the provisions of this chapter shall canvass,
peddle or solicit, except between 10:00 a.m. local time and 8:00 p.m. local
time or sunset, whichever is earlier.
   (c)   No canvasser, peddler or solicitor shall enter or attempt to enter the
house, apartment, or other dwelling unit of any resident in the City without an
express invitation from the occupant of the dwelling unit.
   (d)   No person subject to the terms of this chapter shall make any false,
fraudulent, misleading or deceptive statement during the course of that
person’s canvassing, peddling or soliciting activity within the City.
   (e)   No person subject to this chapter shall canvass, solicit or peddle at
any location where canvassers, solicitors or peddlers are notified by a sign
that such activities are prohibited as provided in Section
723.05.
   (f)   No canvasser, peddler or solicitor shall engage in or transact any
type of business or activity other than that specified on his or her
registration or license.
      (Ord. 1-12.  Passed 3-12-12.)
723.05  TRESPASSING IN VIOLATION OF POSTED SIGNS.
   No person while engaged in canvassing, peddling or soliciting, shall knock
at the door or ring the bell of any house, apartment, apartment building or
other dwelling unit in the City upon which is displayed at the entrance a
notice that reads “No Canvassers, Peddlers or Solicitors Allowed”, or which
otherwise clearly purports to prohibit canvassers, peddlers or solicitors on
the premises, unless such canvasser, peddler or solicitor is, or has been
invited upon the premises by the owners, lessee or occupant thereof.
(Ord. 1-12.  Passed 3-12-12.)
723.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.  Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1-12.  Passed 3-12-12.)
CHAPTER 731
Junk Yards
731.01   Definitions.
731.02   State license required.
731.03   Municipal  license required; fences and plantings.
731.04   Application for license.
731.05   Maintenance of fences.
731.06   Inspection.
731.07   Procedure against violators.
731.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State licensing provisions - see Ohio R.C. 4737.05 et seq.
 
731.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Automobile graveyard" means any establishment or place of business
which is maintained, used, or operated for storing, keeping, buying, or selling
wrecked, scrapped, ruined, or dismantled motor vehicles or motor vehicle parts.
   (b)   "Fence" means a barrier at least six feet in height, constructed of
nontransparent material, and maintained so as to obscure the junk from the
ordinary view of persons passing on state, county, municipal, and township
highways, roads, and streets covered by this chapter.
   (c)   "Interstate system" means the system of highways as defined in the
"Act of August 27, 1958," 72 Stat. 887, 23 U.S.C.A. 103 (D), as amended.
   (d)   "Junk" means old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, trash, waste,
batteries, rubber, iron, steel, and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous
materials.
   (e)   "Junkyard" means an establishment or place of business which is
maintained or operated for the purpose of storing, keeping, buying, or selling
junk, and includes garbage dumps and sanitary landfills. The term also includes
scrap metal processing facilities which are located within 1,000 feet of the
nearest edge of the right-of-way of a highway in the interstate or primary
system. The term does not include junkyards located within areas adjacent to
the interstate system and the primary system which are within 1,000 feet of the
nearest edge of the right-of-way and which are zoned industrial, or which are
not zoned under authority of state or local law, regulation, or ordinance, but
are used for industrial activities as determined by the Ohio Director of
Transportation.
   (f)   "Primary system" means that portion of the highway system designated
by the Ohio Director of Transportation which has been approved by the Secretary
of Transportation of the United States, pursuant to the "Act of August 27,
1958," 72 Stat. 887, 23 U.S.C.A. 103 (B), as amended.
   (g)   "Scrap metal processing facility" means an establishment having
facilities for processing iron, steel, or nonferrous scrap, and whose principal
product is scrap iron and steel or nonferrous scrap for sale for remelting
purposes.
      (1980 Code 120.01)
731.02  STATE LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall operate or maintain a junkyard adjacent to the
interstate or primary systems inside the Municipality, except in zoned or
unzoned industrial areas, unless he has obtained a license issued under Ohio
R.C. 4737.05 through 4737.12. The exception shall not prohibit the regulation
or prohibition of junkyards in zoned or unzoned industrial areas by the
Municipality.
   (b)   No licensee shall operate or maintain a junkyard in violation of the
provisions of this chapter.
(1980 Code 120.02)
731.03  MUNICIPAL LICENSE REQUIRED; FENCES AND PLANTINGS.
   (a)   Any person operating or maintaining a junkyard within 1,000 feet of
the nearest edge of the right-of-way of a state or county road or within 300
feet of the nearest edge of the right-of-way of a township road, prior to
January 1, 1964, shall within one year thereafter, erect the required fence or
make suitable plantings if such junkyard is not obscured by natural objects or
a fence. If, after January 1, 1964, a junkyard is established within 1,000 feet
of the nearest edge of the right-of-way of a state or county highway or within
300 feet of the nearest edge of the right- of-way of a township road, it shall
be located so that the view thereof from such road is obscured by natural
objects or a fence.
   (b)   No person shall operate and maintain a junkyard adjacent to the
interstate or primary systems within the Municipality, except in zoned or
unzoned industrial areas, without obtaining a license to do so from the
Municipal Administrator. Any person operating or maintaining a junkyard within
1,000 feet of the nearest edge of the right-of-way of an interstate or primary
highway within the Municipality except in a zoned or unzoned industrial area,
prior to the effective date of this section, shall, within one year thereafter,
erect the required fence or make suitable plantings if such junkyard is not
screened by natural objects or a fence. This exception shall not prohibit the
regulation or prohibition of junkyards in zoned or unzoned industrial areas by
the Municipality. If a junkyard is established after the effective date of this
section within 1,000 feet of the nearest edge of the right-of-way of an
interstate or primary highway, it shall be located so that the view thereof
from such highway is obscured by natural objects or a fence. If the yard is
obscured, the person operating or maintaining it shall be issued a license
under this section. No license shall be issued unless the yard complies with
the provisions of this section.
   (c)   The fee for a license under this section shall be $25.00. All licenses
issued under this section shall expire on December 31 following the date of
issue. A license may be renewed from year to year on paying the Municipal
Administrator $10.00 for each such renewal.
   (d)   All fees paid under this section shall be for the use of the
Municipality.
   (e)   Any license or renewal thereof issued under this section may be
revoked by the Municipal Administrator, after reasonable notice and opportunity
to be heard, for any violation of this chapter or of Ohio R.C. 4737.01 through
4737.12, by the licensee or by any of his officers, agents, or employees.
Whenever a license has been revoked under this section, the Municipal
Administrator shall not issue another licenses to such licensee, to the husband
or wife of such licensee, or to any partnership or corporation of which he is
an officer or member, until such licensee complies with the provisions of this
chapter or of Ohio R.C. 4737.01 through 4737.12.
(1980 Code 120.03)
731.04  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for a license to operate and maintain a junkyard or for a
renewal thereof shall be made in writing, accompanied by the proper fee, to the
Municipal Administrator, setting forth the name and address of the applicant;
the location of the junkyard; if the applicant is a firm, partnership, or
association, the names and addresses of each member; if the applicant is a
corporation, the date and place of incorporation and the names and addresses of
its officers and directors; and such other reasonable information as the
Municipal Administrator deems necessary. The application shall be signed and
sworn to by the applicant.
(1980 Code 120.04)
731.05  MAINTENANCE OF FENCES.
   Any fence constructed under this chapter shall be neatly constructed, shall
be nontransparent, and shall be kept in good order and repair. No advertisement
shall be permitted thereon other than the name of the person under whose name
the license has been issued and the nature of the business conducted therein.
(1980 Code 120.05)
731.06  INSPECTION.
   (a)   Twice annually the Chief of Police shall inspect every licensed
junkyard in the Municipality, to obtain information with regard to whether the
licensee's business has been and is being conducted in accordance with this
chapter and Ohio R.C. 4737.01 through 4737.12. The Chief of Police shall submit
a written report of each such examination to the Solicitor.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall, for the purpose of this examination, have
free access to the grounds and buildings used in the conduct of the junkyard
business by the licensee.
   (c)   Such inspections may be made at any time, at the option of the Chief
of Police during the regular work hours of the licensee or within the hours of
8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday.
(1980 Code 120.06)
731.07  PROCEDURE AGAINST VIOLATORS.
   Whenever the Solicitor is of the opinion that a junkyard is being operated
or maintained in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter and Ohio
R.C. 4737.05 through 4737.12, he may apply to a court of competent
jurisdiction, alleging the violation complained of and praying for an
injunction or other proper relief. In such case the court may order such
junkyard abated as a nuisance or make such other order as may be proper. An
action brought under this section shall not be deemed to be a bar to a
prosecution under Section
731.99.
(1980 Code 120.07)
731.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the first degree. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
CHAPTER 741
Outdoor Public Entertainment Activity
741.01   Definitions.
741.02   Registration required by sponsoring agency and operator.
741.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63, 3765.02
State licensing of portable amusement devices - see Ohio R.C. 1711.11(H)
County license for public shows - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3765
 
741.01  DEFINITIONS.
   Unless otherwise expressly stated in this chapter, the following terms shall
have the meanings provided in this section.
   (a)   “Operator” means the person, firm, partnership, corporation, club,
society or other legal entity that operates or supervises any outdoor public
entertainment activity or constructs structures incident to outdoor public
entertainment.
   (b)   “Outdoor public entertainment” means any carnival, fair, festival or
similar enterprise which offers to the public, for a fee, any one or
combination of:  amusement rides; games of chance for which prizes may be
awarded; sales of food or beverages; exposition of or offer for sale of goods;
entertainment performance or series of performances; or musical concert.
   (c)   “Sponsoring agency” means the person, firm, partnership, corporation,
club, society or other legal entity that organizes, funds, promotes or sponsors
any outdoor public entertainment.
741.02  REGISTRATION REQUIRED BY SPONSORING AGENCY AND OPERATOR.
   (a)   No sponsoring agency shall conduct or operate or allow to be conducted
or operated any outdoor public entertainment within the Municipality without
prior approved registration with the Municipal Administrator.
   (b)   No operator shall operate any form of outdoor public entertainment
without prior approved registration with the Municipal Administrator.
   (c)   Such registration will be completed to the satisfaction of the
Municipal Administrator on forms prescribed by such Administrator.
741.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00).  Each day constitutes a separate violation.
CHAPTER 751
Video Service Providers
751.01   VSP fee established.
751.02   Allocation of funds.
 
751.01  VSP FEE ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of five percent (5%) to the video service provider’s gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332(B) of the Video Law.  For purposes of
calculating the VSP Fee, the provider’s gross revenues shall include
advertising revenues in accordance with Section 1332.23(B)(2)(g) of the Video
Law.  The VSP Fee Percentage and Video Law gross revenues definition, as
modified in this section, shall apply equally to all video service providers
and cable television operators providing video service in the Municipality.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the Municipality on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five
(45) days nor later than sixty (60) days after the end of each calendar
quarter.
   (c)   The Municipal Administrator is authorized and directed to provide any
video service provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage and gross revenues
definition as determined by this Council above, which notice shall be given by
certified mail, upon receipt of notice from such video service provider that it
will begin providing video service in the Municipality pursuant to a state-
issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 01-08.  Passed 1-14-08.)
751.02  ALLOCATION OF FUNDS.
   The funds collected under the provisions of this chapter shall be applied
for the following purposes:
   (a)   One hundred percent (100%) of the Video Service Provider Fees received
annually shall be paid into the Parks and Green Space Fund and shall be set
aside and used for purposes benefitting parks and green spaces within the
Municipality.
   (b)   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) hereof, for the
entire calendar year 2010, one hundred percent (100%) of the Video Service
Provider Fees received under the provisions of this chapter shall be paid into
the General Fund to pay the operating expenses of the Municipality.
      (Ord. 35-09.  Passed 1-25-10.)

CHAPTER 905
Weeds and Grass
905.01   Rank growth and noxious weeds a nuisance.
905.02   Cutting and clearing required.
905.03   Notice to cut and clear.
905.04   Municipal work; expenses assessed.
905.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Noxious weeds - see Ohio R.C. 731.51 et seq.
Destructions of weeds - see Ohio R.C. 971.33 et seq.
 
905.01  RANK GROWTH AND NOXIOUS WEEDS A NUISANCE.
   Council determines that noxious weeds, including, but not limited to,
thistle, burdock, jimson weed, wild lettuce, wild mustard, ragweed, milkweed,
and poison ivy, and other vegetation of rank growth within the Municipality are
injurious to the public health and safety, and they and any land covered
thereby are declared to be a public nuisance.
(1980 Code 94.01; Ord. 9-88.)
905.02  CUTTING AND CLEARING REQUIRED.
   No person, whether as owner, lessee, agent, tenant or otherwise having
charge or care of land within the Municipality, shall permit noxious weeds or
other undesirable vegetation, including grasses, to grow thereon to a height in
excess of 12 inches; or shall permit such noxious weeds or other undesirable
vegetation to mature or spread seeds or pollen therefrom.  However, certain
parcels of land may be, upon application to and approval by the Municipal
Administrator, exempted from the provisions of this chapter where such parcels
are dedicated to and officially designated as park lands for the preservation
of natural wild life; or where geographic contours or other terrain features of
a part of any parcel of land would make compliance with the provisions of this
chapter an extreme hardship as to that specific portion of the land.  Land that
is designed to be used for the retention or detention of stormwater shall also
be exempted from the provisions of this chapter.  Specifically, the vegetation
on all lands adjoining or contiguous with the intersection of any road or
highway shall be cut, as required by this section, to prevent the growth of any
vegetation which would obscure the visibility or vision of road or highway
users or otherwise create any traffic hazard.
(Ord. 26-15.  Passed 10-12-15.)
905.03  NOTICE TO CUT AND CLEAR.
   (a)   Upon information that noxious weeds or other vegetation of rank growth
are growing on lands within the Municipality or are about to mature or spread
seeds or pollen, the Municipal Administrator shall cause notice to be served on
the owners or persons having charge of such lands that such weeds and
vegetation must be cut and destroyed within five days after the date of such
notice.
   (b)   If the owner or other person having charge of the land is a
nonresident of the municipal corporation whose address is known, the notice
shall be sent to his address by certified mail. If the address of the owner or
other person having charge of the land is unknown, it is sufficient to publish
the notice once in a newspaper of general circulation in the County.
(1980 Code 94.03; Ord. 9-88.)
905.04  MUNICIPAL WORK; EXPENSES ASSESSED.
   If the owner or person having charge of such land fails to comply with the
notice referred to in Section
905.03, the Municipal Administrator may cause such weeds and vegetation to be
cut or destroyed. The cost and expense thereof shall, when approved by Council,
be assessed against such lands and certified and collected as provided by law
in the case of other assessments levied by Council. The expense assessed shall
include the cost of any publication or publications pursuant to this chapter,
and the cost and expense of levying and collecting such assessments. All
expenses and costs assessed pursuant to this section shall be in addition to
any penalty provided for in Section
905.99.
(1980 Code 94.04; Ord. 403.)
905.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with any
of such provisions is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for each offense. Each week
that a condition in violation of the provisions of this chapter is permitted to
continue shall constitute a separate offense.
(1980 Code 94.99)
CHAPTER 907
Trees and Shrubs
